review.title: “Overworked and under-appreciated”
review.pros: Pros – There's a decent pension scheme and adequate discount which is increased at holiday times throughout the year. There are plenty of opportunities to attend Food Colleges in some departments, which can lead to NVQs in subjects relevant to your current role, which can then be transferred on. There are also some genuinely delightful customers who make it all (briefly) seem worthwhile.
review.cons: Cons – I have never worked for a company with such blatant disregard and disrespect for the well-being of its staff. On food service departments, scheduled hours are slashed to the bone meaning colleagues receive a bare minimum of breaks and sometimes go hours without even a drink of water, as it's apparently prohibited to consume anything behind the counter, and are often expected to assist other departments even though their counter is single-staffed and this means leaving it empty. Company rules state strict hygiene and apparel rules,which are flagrantly flouted by management, as it doesn't apply to them, apparently. There is a group who are 'in' with management and therefore get away with floating about and doing as little as they can manage, while the rest of us work like dogs to keep standards up. If you work over your shift time, you won't get paid - this is expected of team leaders who get treated like the scum of the earth by management and sometimes by colleagues, with no comeback whatsoever. It is an absolute joke that one of this company's mission statements is 'respect for the individual'. No consideration is given to colleagues who have families outwith the "2.5 children" scenario leading to terrible work-life balance for colleagues who may also have demanding personal schedules albeit without any child-rearing duties. Rules very strict on absence with no consideration given to those with chronic conditions or hidden disabilities, even after meeting with management to resolve issues, they are told that the "needs of the business" outweigh their own personal considerations.From a business standpoint, the focus is very clearly on customer service, and yet colleagues who spend too much time with a customer (helping an elderly customer with their shopping, for example, or advising a customer on a recipe for the product they are buying) will receive a tongue-lashing. Much is made of their "legal documentation to prove due diligence" and yet colleagues are advised to falsify these or "just sign it" and even when arguing their case are told that they are in the wrong for following the correct procedure they were explicitly trained to follow. Lip service is paid to being safe and legal but to all intents and purposes it is only lip service and management clearly don't care if they endanger their staff and customers, as long as they can say "oh, we're compliant" and keep raking in the profits.Lack of organisation: may be unique to my store, doubtful though that is. HR constantly and consistently "lose" papers submitted to them - expenses receipts, schedules, and worst of all training booklets. Some colleagues have been repeatedly trained and signed off on the same modules, the paperwork submitted, only to have it mysteriously go missing and the colleague being dressed down for non-completion. I myself am on my fourth copy of a certain module. Repeat training must cost a fortune in paper and colleague hours and certainly engenders a lot of ill-will towards the idling HR colleagues.All in all the store would not be unpleasant to work in if it were not for the constant procedure 180 turns, appalling disorganization and mis-communication, or the daily microagressions and complaints of management leveled at colleagues who are already working near flat-out just to complete their daily tasks.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please start treating colleagues respectfully and as people, not as brain-dead automatons without any spark of creative thought or knowledge. Start listening to local knowledge and stop treating every store as if it were a big city superstore. Recognize the strengths you have in your colleagues instead of insisting they all perform in exactly the same way, and then criticizing them when they cannot perform at superhuman levels for extended periods of time.

review.title: “I've been here a long time so it can't be that bad”

The company's policy is that if the employees are happy, so will the customers.- Good, mostly worthwhile, training.- Lots of opportunities for extra work.

review.employee-type: General Assistant (Shelf Stacker), Fresh Foods (Former Employee)
review.title: “If you have to work in a supermarket, you could do a lot worse”
review.pros: Pros – The trouble with reviewing retail firms is that it's impossible to say whether my experience is representative of other stores.Nonetheless, I was fairly impressed by the senior colleagues at the store I worked at though - they got things done with the minimum of slave driving, and treated you as a person. Not a lot to ask for I guess, but probably shouldn't be taken for granted in this sector.Sainsburys does seem to be genuinely trying to invest in the development of shop floor colleagues - via both promotion and job rotation. While I wouldn't expect to go from checkout to boardroom, competent (and inevitably incompetent) staff who stick around seem to get promoted, eventually. Don't get me wrong - it's still a dead end job, but by the standards of retail Sainsburys isn't probably a bad place to be a till monkey.Benefits (paid holidays, discount, pension, ect) seem pretty good - if your plan to to supermarket work for the long haul, god help you then Sainsburys probably isn't a bad place to be.
review.cons: Cons – Pay, obviously: though £6.44/hour basic [that's with London weighting] is pretty average for retail work. Your bonus for hitting sales/mystery customer targets is a mere 1% though. Compare that to 15% at a Tesco I worked at a few years back (again, not sure how representative these figures are for other stores).As you can probably guess, the work ranges from bearable to soul-destroying. Obviously a lot depends on your actual role, colleagues, and temperament, but there's no getting away from the fact that shelf stacking/till work is about as menial as it gets. if you can hack doing the same thing every day with very little development or variety then you'll be fine.A small minority of customers seem to get kicks from talking down to you. Again, probably par for the course for retail.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop messing about giving 1% bonuses to shop floor colleagues. Up it to double digits, or just don't bother.Other than that JS seems to be in a good place at the moment. Keep up the good work, and don't take your eye off the ball.

review.title: “Low wages”

review.cons: Cons – The work I was doing was boring. But that wasn't the fault of management. Shelf stacking would be dull in any supermarket.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Increase the wages and incentives offered.

review.employee-type: Stock Control and Warehouse Manager (Former Employee)
review.title: “Making Life taste Better????”
review.pros: Pros – The discount scheme is not the best in comparison with other retailers, but it is increased at holiday times and during the summer and you can get some excellent bargains amongst the sale items and the seasonal offers;As the store is open long hours it is possible to arrange hours around outside commitments such as child care and medical appointments which means that holiday s do not need to be used; there is a fairly generous holiday allowance given plus the bank holidays, you can opt to work the bank holidays and have an alternative day off providing it fits in with the needs of the business. some stores have a very good atmosphere and friendly staff
review.cons: Cons – There are constant changes to processes and procedures that sometimes hard to implement and sell to the staff and just as everyone adjusts it changes. It would appear that some decisions are made by people at the top who have never worked in a store or it has not been trialled properly. Information is given out on a need to know basis with the idea that no one needs to know. communication has improved but it is still not good enough. The stores get the blame for most things and have to take the cost of any losses. The depots cause problems at times, but have improved greatly. System information is not available at store level that would help resolve problems and provide proof that deliveries are not accurate. Staff employed on night shift are a law unto themselves, are often not able to read english sufficiently to do a good job and this causes problems for day staff. If you have no family life then this is an ideal job as it can take over your life if you let it. Power hungry kingdom builders are often allowed to get away with their appalling behaviour
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Value your good staff - don't burn them - or they will leave

review.title: “favouritism leads the way”
review.pros: Pros – If you get in with the right group you can work your way around the departments quite easily. Being on checkouts it is quite easy to avoid serving customers if you are pally with the supervisor, instead being put to do left behinds - walking around the store for however long you decide to take, or baskets/trolleys.Having an office job is another way of saying you're lazy. Most office workers spend a lot of time sat at their desk getting the bare minimum done and delegating to others on their department.
review.cons: Cons – The managers seem incapable of encouraging the members of staff, HR treats staff with contempt. If you go to them too often with queries or complaints they will do very little to help you and during a recent reshuffle of hours they acted with favouritism when it came to being forced to do unfavourable hours over favourable ones. Career opportunities are unfairly given out with the same favoured few being tossed from department to department when they get bored of whichever role they are playing at this week.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The senior management need to actively try to motivate the people at store level who are the face of the company they are trying to change. They give us all these targets we should be meeting but instead of motivating us they are telling us it's the way things are. If they want the company to improve they have to have better delegation down the line

review.title: “Sainsbury's no worse than any other retail group”
review.pros: Pros – Good progression for career, company is more interested in your experience than what qualifications you have. Always improving and wanting to succeed even more so through the bad times.
review.cons: Cons – Work life balance is very poor. Work over your hours on a daily basis. Shift times change on a weekly basis, sometimes daily, unable to plan anything outside of work, unless booking as holiday.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Remember that we can't do impossable. We all want to succeed, but allow us to be able to interact with customers and colleagues, without feeling that we havn't got the time.

review.title: “Variety great, pay disappointing”
review.pros: Pros – The role had lots of variety and could involve anything from conducting disciplinary hearings with employees to stacking freezers on the shop floor. All roles customer facing and if you enjoy working and dealing with people then this role is for you. There is a lot of scope for "on the job training" as the approach is very much "get stuck in" so if you like a challenge and picking things up as you go along this role will suit you
review.cons: Cons – The pay was certainly on the low side and sometimes the hours can be unsociable as operations are 24 hours seven days a week. The lack of career progression opportunties was certainly a drawback as was the support available for more formalised personal development and training
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Paying people slightly above minimum wage is no good for staff retention

review.title: “could do better in staff relations”
review.pros: Pros – job security staff discount pension plan
review.cons: Cons – the hours are sometimes insociable, but this is I suppose to be expected in a retail environment. customers are I find much ruder than they used to be, and I think this is partly because we pander to their every whim. Whilst I agree that sometimes the customer is right, not always so and this reflects in their attitude to the staff. A more positive attitude towards staff would result in a happier working atmosphere
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – to be more receptive and friendly towards staff and to realise that it is us who are dealing face to face with the public and thus providing THEM with their bonuses!! We are also human and a Good morning or acknowledgment would do wonders for morale, praise as well as criticism would go a long way to making it 'GREAT' again!!

review.title: “sounds great but then reality bites!”
review.pros: Pros – The concept of the values is great and the board seem to display these.
review.cons: Cons – managersdo not live the values or behaviours
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – For the board to have 1 2 1 s with middle to lower management to understand how life really is.Not group discussions where colleaguesfear to speak.

review.title: “Good for part time work, not so good for full time”
review.pros: Pros – To meet new people and interact with customers. If you like knowing what goes on behind the scenes of companies, then Sainsburys is a good place to work. The staff discount is also a bonus and the feeling that you have helped customers.
review.cons: Cons – The pay isn't very enticing, and management can be awkward when trying to book time off.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The store manager needs to interact with employees more and give them praise for doing jobs well. He also needs to spend more time on the shop floor, taking part in jobs there, to see how the store is operating.
